item.title: At Least 55 Dead in Hong Kong Apartment Fire
item.description: Firefighters were still trying to fully extinguish the blaze more than 24 hours after it engulfed several towers in the complex. Dozens of people were still missing.
item.dc:creator: The New York Times
item.media:credit: Lam Yik Fei for The New York Times

item.title: Pope Leo Lands in Turkey, Planning to Meet Erdogan With a Message of Outreach
item.description: President Recep Tayyip Erdogan received Leo XIV on the opening leg of a trip that will also include Lebanon.
item.dc:creator: Ben Hubbard and Motoko Rich
item.media:credit: Diego Ibarra Sanchez for The New York Times
item.media:description: Pope Leo XIV on Thursday visited the mausoleum of Mustafa Kemal Ataturk, the founder of modern Turkey and its first president.

item.title: Rocket Attack on Iraqi Gas Field Cuts Power to Most of Kurdistan
item.description: The strike is the latest in a string of attacks on energy infrastructure in Iraq’s northern Kurdish region, which some regional authorities have privately blamed on Iran-affiliated militias.
item.dc:creator: Erika Solomon
item.category: Islamic State in Iraq and Syria (ISIS)
item.media:description: The Khor Mor gas field after a rocket attack in Iraq’s Kurdistan region on Thursday.

item.title: Trump Cut Europe Out of Ukraine Talks. Here’s How Europe Pushed Back.
item.description: European leaders were blindsided by President Trump’s 28-point-plan to end the Ukraine war, setting off a dash for influence.
item.dc:creator: Jeanna Smialek, Christopher F. Schuetze and Lara Jakes
item.media:description: President Trump with Secretary of State Marco Rubio in the Netherlands in June.

item.title: Putin Defends Witkoff Against Accusations of Pro-Russia Bias
item.description: The Russian leader called the U.S. special envoy “an intelligent man” who is properly representing his country in peace negotiations.
item.dc:creator: Paul Sonne
item.media:description: A photo released by Russian state media showed President Vladimir V. Putin meeting with Steve Witkoff in Moscow in August. The two are scheduled to meet again next week.

item.title: What to Know About the Coup in Guinea-Bissau
item.description: The opposition has accused the president of putting a general in charge of the government so that he could stay in power and lead by proxy.
item.dc:creator: Saikou Jammeh and Ruth Maclean
item.category: Coups D'Etat and Attempted Coups D'Etat
item.media:description: General Horta Inta-a during his swearing-in ceremony as the transitional leader of Guinea-Bissau.

item.title: Hong Kong’s Worst Fire in Decades Fuels Scrutiny of Safety Lapses
item.description: The authorities said flammable netting and foam boards may have fueled the city’s deadliest blaze in nearly 80 years, killing more than 90 and prompting arrests.
item.dc:creator: Alexandra Stevenson, Joy Dong, Tiffany May and Keith Bradsher

item.title: Russia Labels Navalny’s Anti-Corruption Group as Terrorist Organization
item.description: A legal assault against the opposition leader’s movement has deepened since his death in prison last year.
item.dc:creator: Nataliya Vasilyeva
item.media:credit: Nanna Heitmann for The New York Times
item.media:description: Flowers and other tributes left on Aleksei A. Navalny’s grave in Moscow after he died in an Arctic penal colony last year.

item.title: Images From the Deadly High-Rise Fire in Hong Kong
item.description: The blaze tore through an apartment complex, killing scores. Dozens more are believed to be missing in what remains of the buildings.
item.dc:creator: The New York Times

item.title: Trump shuts the door to Afghans who face crises at home.
item.dc:creator: Elian Peltier
item.media:credit: Jim Huylebroek for The New York Times
item.media:description: Residents filling up barrels during a water shortage in Kabul, Afghanistan, this year. The country has been gripped by humanitarian crises under Taliban rule.

item.title: France Creates Voluntary Military Service as Europe Faces Russian Threat
item.description: The effort, aimed at young people, came after an army chief angered many by saying the country must accept the possible loss of “our children” in a future war.
item.dc:creator: Ségolène Le Stradic
item.media:description: President Emmanuel Macron of France on Thursday in the French Alps, where he announced a paid, voluntary military service.

item.title: The British Public Thinks Immigration Is Up. It’s Actually Down, Sharply.
item.description: Net migration to Britain has fallen by almost 80 percent from its 2023 peak, according to data released on Thursday.
item.dc:creator: Michael D. Shear
item.media:description: Anti-migrant protesters outside a hotel in Scotland in August. Despite public perception, migrants who come ashore on small boats represent a fraction of overall immigration to Britain.

item.title: Pope Leo Visits Turkey on His First Trip as Pontiff
item.description: The pope started his six-day trip, which will also include a visit to Lebanon.
item.dc:creator: The New York Times
item.media:credit: Diego Ibarra Sanchez for The New York Times
item.media:description: Pope Leo XIV at the Ataturk Mausoleum in Ankara, Turkey.

item.title: Hong Kongers Volunteer to Help Fire Victims
item.description: Residents from across the city have quickly organized to donate food, water, clothing and other supplies in Tai Po for the many displaced people.
item.dc:creator: Tiffany May

item.title: Sri Lanka on High Alert as Cyclone Death Toll Reaches 56
item.description: Heavy rainfall was forecast for nearly all of the island nation as Cyclone Ditwah churned northwest toward India.
item.dc:creator: Pamodi Waravita
item.media:description: Storm damage in Colombo, Sri Lanka’s capital, on Friday.

item.title: In Turkey, Pope Seeks to Soothe an Ancient Christian Divide
item.description: In Istanbul, Pope Leo XIV will meet the patriarch of the Eastern Orthodox Church to show amity between two of the world’s largest Christian groups.
item.dc:creator: Ben Hubbard
item.media:credit: Bradley Secker for The New York Times
item.media:description: Tourists light candles during a visit to the Theological School of Halki, an Orthodox seminary shuttered by the Turkish government.

item.title: Did Myanmar’s Junta Demolish Scam Centers Just for Show?
item.description: Myanmar’s junta made a grand display of demolishing buildings that hosted the centers, even broadcasting the explosions. But the scammers have found new homes.
item.dc:creator: Sui-Lee Wee
item.media:description: KK Park, a large scam center in eastern Myanmar, seen from Mae Sot District in Thailand in September.

item.title: Carney Lifts Climate Laws for New Alberta Pipeline
item.description: Prime Minister Mark Carney reached a tentative deal with the province as part of his program to curb the country’s economic dependence on the United States.
item.dc:creator: Ian Austen
item.media:description: Prime Minister Mark Carney with Premier Danielle Smith of Alberta on Thursday in Calgary.

item.title: Louvre Raising Ticket Prices for Non-European Visitors
item.description: From Jan. 14, visitors to the museum from outside the European Economic Area will pay 45 percent more for entry to help finance its ambitious renovation plan.
item.dc:creator: Ségolène Le Stradic and Alex Marshall
item.media:credit: Dmitry Kostyukov for The New York Times
item.media:description: The Louvre is still on the mend after thieves broke into one of its galleries in October and stole about $100 million worth of jewelry.

item.title: A.I. and the Trillion-Dollar Question
item.description: Even the companies building the technology don’t seem exactly sure where it’s headed.
item.dc:creator: Katrin Bennhold
item.media:credit: Eric Lee for The New York Times
item.media:description: The chip-making giant Nvidia’s valuation topped $5 trillion last month.

item.title: Why Is the U.S. Threatening Venezuela?
item.description: Venezuela doesn’t play a large role in the drug trade to the United States, so what is motivating the massive military buildup? Julian E. Barnes, who reports on intelligence and international security, discusses the issues with our senior writer Katrin Bennhold.
item.dc:creator: Julian E. Barnes, Katrin Bennhold, Nikolay Nikolov, Leila Medina, Lazaro Gamio, Samuel Granados and Stephanie Swart

item.title: ‘No Alarm Went Off’: Hong Kong Fire Survivor Recounts Harrowing Escape
item.description: Many windows were covered, preventing residents from seeing the fire and smoke, one survivor said.
item.dc:creator: Joy Dong
item.media:credit: Lam Yik Fei for The New York Times
item.media:description: A survivor said the fire moved with terrible speed as it seemed to climb up the tall apartment towers and then jump across the gaps between them.

item.title: Here’s the latest.
item.dc:creator: Joy Dong, Alexandra Stevenson and Keith Bradsher

item.title: Heading to the Mideast, Pope Leo May Show ‘Who He Really Is’
item.description: The pontiff begins a trip to Turkey and Lebanon on Thursday — the first foreign voyage of his papacy, and his biggest test yet.
item.dc:creator: Motoko Rich
item.media:credit: Diego Ibarra Sanchez for The New York Times
item.media:description: Pope Leo XIV at the Ataturk Mausoleum in Ankara, Turkey, on Thursday.

item.title: Hong Kong Arrests 3 Tied to Construction Company After Deadly Apartment Fire
item.description: The police said that building materials used by the company for the work at Wang Fuk Court may not have been up to fire safety standards. The police did not identify the company or who was arrested.
item.dc:creator: Alexandra Stevenson
item.media:description: Hong Kong firefighters battling the blaze at Wang Fuk Court on Wednesday night.

item.title: U.S. to Press Europe and Other Allies on Immigration, Document Says
item.description: American diplomats were told to raise U.S. concerns about “violent crimes associated with people of a migration background.”
item.dc:creator: Edward Wong and Hamed Aleaziz

item.title: Trump Says South Africa Is Not Invited to G20 Summit in U.S. in 2026
item.description: The president did not attend this year’s annual gathering in South Africa, which has been a frequent target of his attacks.
item.dc:creator: John Eligon
item.media:description: President Cyril Ramaphosa of South Africa addresses the opening session of the G20 leaders’ summit, in Johannesburg.

item.title: As Trade Talks Stall, Carney Moves to Shield Canada from Trump Tariffs
item.description: Prime Minister Mark Carney announced curbs on steel imports, a new tariff and help with steel and lumber freight costs in a bid to aid Canadian industries.
item.dc:creator: Ian Austen
item.media:credit: Adrian Wyld/The Canadian Press, via Associated Press
item.media:description: Prime Minister Mark Carney of Canada arriving on Parliament Hill in Ottawa on Wednesday.

item.title: E.P.A. Delays Requirements to Cut Methane, a Potent Greenhouse Gas
item.description: Oil and gas firms were supposed to start reducing methane, a powerful driver of climate change. The agency is giving them more time and may cancel the requirement.
item.dc:creator: Lisa Friedman and Maxine Joselow
item.media:credit: Desiree Rios for The New York Times
item.media:description: A gas flare at an oil facility in Midland, Texas.

item.title: Top U.S. Negotiator Warned Europeans That Russia Is Stockpiling Missiles
item.description: Daniel P. Driscoll, the U.S. Army secretary, used the growing threat from Moscow as a way to sell a quick peace deal unfavorable to Ukraine.
item.dc:creator: Andrew E. Kramer
item.media:description: Piles of spent Russian missiles at a “graveyard” for war ordnance in the Kharkiv region of Ukraine in July.

item.title: Dubrovnik, Known for Its Beauty, Faces a Mound of New Trash
item.description: Officials in Dubrovnik, Croatia, say the strong currents of the Adriatic Sea washed ashore a vast amount of garbage, mostly from Albania, during a recent storm.
item.dc:creator: Adeel Hassan
item.media:description: Banje Beach is the most popular beach on Croatia’s shore, but there were no sunbathers on Wednesday.

item.title: U.K. Budget Plan Calms Markets and Labour Faithful. Will It Appeal to Voters?
item.description: The plan presented by the chancellor of the Exchequer, Rachel Reeves, called for spending increases and higher taxes on the wealthy and the middle class.
item.dc:creator: Mark Landler
item.media:description: Rachel Reeves, Britain’s chancellor of the Exchequer, carries a red box symbolizing the presentation of a new government budget on Wednesday in London.

item.title: An Asia-Pacific Showdown
item.description: China and Japan are in a diplomatic feud over Taiwan, with President Trump in the middle.
item.dc:creator: Katrin Bennhold
item.media:description: Prime Minister Sanae Takaichi of Japan and China’s leader, Xi Jinping.

item.title: Deadly, fast-moving fire is less likely in Midtown Manhattan, experts say.
item.description: The area’s high-rises have robust safety features and are not as densely packed as those in Hong Kong, making them less susceptible to blazes.
item.dc:creator: Camille Baker and Mihir Zaveri
item.media:credit: Karsten Moran for The New York Times
item.media:description: New York City pioneered high-rise firefighting tactics.

item.title: Hong Kong Residents Describe How Apartment Fire Quickly Spread
item.description: Residents describe how a blaze in a high-rise building in Hong Kong quickly spread, taking many by surprise and trapping an unknown number of people in the burning buildings.
item.dc:creator: Joy Dong
item.media:description: A fire that began in the midafternoon in Hong Kong quickly spread to nearby buildings in the Wang Fuk Court residential complex.

item.title: Hong Kong Fire Shared Similarities With Grenfell Tower Fire in London
item.description: In the Grenfell Tower blaze, a combustible element called cladding that ran up the outside of the 24-story building allowed the fire to jump from floor to floor.
item.dc:creator: James Glanz
item.media:credit: Victoria Jones/PA Wire, via Associated Press
item.media:description: The Grenfell Tower in London caught fire in 2017, killing dozens of people.

item.title: Italy Passes a Femicide Law, Seeking to Prevent Violence Against Women
item.description: Murders of women killed for misogynistic reasons will now be classified as femicide. Campaigners say a broader cultural shift is still needed.
item.dc:creator: Elisabetta Povoledo
item.media:description: Pallbearers carry the coffin of Giulia Cecchettin, a 22-year-old university student who was killed by her ex-boyfriend in 2023.

item.title: What to Know About the Deadly Fire at a Hong Kong Apartment Complex
item.description: At least 94 people were killed in the most lethal fire in Hong Kong in nearly 70 years. Firefighters had extinguished most of the blaze by Friday morning.
item.dc:creator: Lynsey Chutel and Francesca Regalado
item.media:credit: Lam Yik Fei for The New York Times
item.media:description: The charred buildings in the Tai Po district of northern Hong Kong on Thursday.

item.title: Guinea-Bissau’s President Says He Has Been Deposed. The Opposition Says It’s a Trick.
item.description: The military announced on Wednesday it had taken over the West African nation. Later, the opposition leader accused the incumbent president of staging the coup d’état to try to retain power.
item.dc:creator: Ruth Maclean
item.category: Coups D'Etat and Attempted Coups D'Etat
item.media:description: Soldiers hold weapons while patrolling a street near the Presidential Palace in Guinea-Bissau on Wednesday.

item.title: Miroslaw Chojecki, Solidarity’s ‘Minister of Smuggling,’ Dies at 76
item.description: First in Warsaw and later from Paris, he supplied anti-Communist activists in Poland with steady stream of leaflets, newsletters and banned books.
item.dc:creator: Clay Risen
item.media:description: Miroslaw Chojecki at a news conference in Manhattan in 1981. For years, he ran a sophisticated smuggling network based in Paris, shipping ink, paper, equipment and books disguised as technical manuals back to Poland.

item.title: Tai Po is a crucial link between Hong Kong and mainland China.
item.description: The city
item.dc:creator: Ravi Mattu
item.media:description: Tai Po is on a bay circled by lush mountains.

item.title: Eli Zeira, 97, Dies; Israeli Official Dismissed Warnings of Yom Kippur War
item.description: As Israel’s head of military intelligence, he disregarded signs Egypt and Syria were about to attack in 1973. A commission blamed him for the lack of preparation.
item.dc:creator: Richard Sandomir and Johnatan Reiss

item.title: Amid Strobes and a Beat Drop, Pope Blesses Rave-Goers
item.description: A papal video message appeared before a crowd of hundreds in Slovakia, as Guilherme Peixoto, a priest who doubles as an electronic D.J., put on a show.
item.dc:creator: Ali Watkins
item.media:description: Pope Leo XIV addressed the crowd on video at a rave in Slovakia earlier this month.

item.title: The last time Hong Kong had a major fire was 2008.
item.description: The last five-alarm fire in Hong Kong engulfed a 15-story building in the Mong Kong district, killing four people.
item.dc:creator: Lynsey Chutel
item.media:description: A fire in the Mong Kok neighborhood of Hong Kong in 2008.

item.title: Nicolas Sarkozy, Former French President, Loses Corruption Appeal
item.description: France’s highest court has upheld a conviction against Nicolas Sarkozy, who led France until 2012. It comes weeks after he was jailed in a different fraud trial.
item.dc:creator: Ségolène Le Stradic
item.media:description: Nicolas Sarkozy, a former president of France, at a soccer match in Paris on Saturday. He had spent 20 days in jail on another case, but was freed after filing an appeal.

item.title: Jakarta Overtakes Tokyo as World’s Largest City, UN Report Says
item.description: The capital of Indonesia surpassed Tokyo as the world’s most populous city after the United Nations overhauled how it measures urban populations.
item.dc:creator: John Yoon
item.media:credit: Nicola Longobardi for The New York Times
item.media:description: View of Jakarta, Indonesia, last year. Jakarta has won the title of the world’s most populated city.

item.title: Deadly Flooding in Thailand Prompts Rescues and Evacuations
item.description: The military sent troops, helicopters and boats to rescue stranded people. At least 33 people have been killed and more than two million displaced over the past week.
item.dc:creator: Francesca Regalado
item.media:description: Cars on a bridge to escape floodwaters in Hat Yai, Thailand, on Tuesday.

item.title: Here’s the latest.
item.description: Firefighters tried to douse the blaze at an apartment complex in the city’s northern Tai Po district, which killed at least four people.
item.dc:creator: Alexandra Stevenson, Joy Dong, Keith Bradsher, Anushka Patil and Tina Zhou

item.title: The Question Hanging Over Peace Talks: What Will Putin Accept?
item.description: A U.S. proposal may cross a number of red lines for the Russian leader, who sees little to lose and much potentially to gain from continuing to fight.
item.dc:creator: Paul Sonne
item.media:credit: Nanna Heitmann for The New York Times
item.media:description: President Vladimir V. Putin in Moscow in 2024. For the Russian leader, holding out for a broader Ukrainian collapse could deliver hitherto unthinkable concessions.

item.title: Venezuela’s Nobel Peace Prize Winner Pushes False Claims About Maduro
item.description: Opposition leader Maria Corina Machado faces criticism that she is exaggerating threats posed by Venezuela’s leader to justify U.S. force to overthrow him.
item.dc:creator: Simon Romero
item.media:credit: Adriana Loureiro Fernandez for The New York Times
item.media:description: Maria Corina Machado has argued that Nicolás Maduro simultaneously heads two different drug trafficking organizations that threaten U.S. national security.

item.title: What’s Really Going On With Crime in South Africa
item.description: Police statistics in South Africa dispute President Trump’s claim that Afrikaners are being targeted in a genocide, but the high murder rate includes victims of all backgrounds. John Eligon, our Johannesburg bureau chief, traveled with several patrol groups in communities of South Africa to explore how the country is dealing with crime.
item.dc:creator: John Eligon, Joao Silva, Christina Thornell, Leila Medina and James Surdam

item.title: ‘Imperial Israel’ in the New Middle East
item.description: Despite a cease-fire with Hezbollah, almost daily strikes demonstrate an emboldened Israel’s strategy to eliminate its enemies any time, anywhere.
item.dc:creator: Roger Cohen and David Guttenfelder
item.category: War Crimes, Genocide and Crimes Against Humanity
Arms Control and Limitation and Disarmament
item.media:description: Israel is striking at will in Lebanon, killing enemies and innocents.

item.title: Trump Vowed Fewer Regulations and Lots More Oil. He’s Delivered on One.
item.description: The president’s energy strategy is projected to generate more pollution, but so far production has not risen significantly and price drops have been modest, analysts say.
item.dc:creator: Lisa Friedman
item.media:description: Since President Trump took office, oil production is up, but largely because of improved efficiency, and it has not translated into more jobs for either the industry or the overall economy.

item.title: Spat With China Becomes an Asset for Japan’s New Leader
item.description: Japan’s prime minister, Sanae Takaichi, is not backing off from comments about Taiwan that enraged China. Many of Japan’s voters like her stance.
item.dc:creator: River Akira Davis and Hisako Ueno

item.title: ‘You Start Getting Desperate’: How It Feels to Be Young and Jobless in Britain
item.description: Rising youth unemployment is one of the challenges that will affect the success of the British chancellor’s economic approach as she unveils a crucial budget on Wednesday.
item.dc:creator: Michael D. Shear and Andrew Testa
item.media:credit: Andrew Testa for The New York Times
item.media:description: McKenzie Bartley, 19, spent months last year applying for jobs in Bristol.

item.title: Pope Leo to Visit Turkey and Lebanon
item.description: Leo XIV will meet political and religious leaders in Turkey and Lebanon, providing an early test of his geopolitical mettle. Here’s what to know.
item.dc:creator: Motoko Rich
item.media:description: Pope Leo XIV greeting the crowd at St Peter’s Square in the Vatican last weekend.

item.title: Taiwan’s President to Seek an Extra $40 Billion for Military
item.description: President Lai Ching-te says the spending, which must be approved by the island’s legislature, would fund purchases of arms from the United States.
item.dc:creator: Chris Buckley and Amy Chang Chien
item.media:description: President Lai Ching-te of Taiwan has come under pressure from the Trump administration to increase the island’s spending on defense.
